bio.title: Author Biographies
bio.p: Florian Baumann worked as a research and teaching assistant at the Johannes Gutenberg University Mainz, Germany, and the Eberhard Karls University Tübingen, Germany, where he also obtained his doctorate in 2007 and currently represents the Chair for Public Finance. His main research interest are in the areas of law and economics, public finance, and labor economics.

Tim Friehe is a professor of law and economics at the Center for Advanced Studies in Law and Economics (CASTLE), University of Bonn. His research specialties include law and economics, public economics, and environmental economics.

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue: The Shadow Economy, Tax Evasion, and Money Laundering

abstract.p: This article analyzes the interaction between tax evasion and tacit collusion. We show that the possibility of evading taxes generally influences the incentives to form a cartel. We establish that whether tax evasion increases or decreases the set of circumstances allowing stable collusion depends on (1) the relation between the benefits of tax evasion and legal after-tax profits and (2) effective enforcement of antitrust laws. In considering variations in tax enforcement and antitrust enforcement, we find that stricter tax enforcement may actually increase the level of tax evasion, as it may promote the cartelization of industries. In contrast, stricter antitrust enforcement lowers incentives for cartelization, thereby possibly reducing tax evasion at the same time.

sec.title: Motivation and Main Result
sec.p: “People of the same trade seldom meet together, even for merriment and diversion, but the conversation ends in a conspiracy against the public, or in some contrivance to raise prices.” This was true in the days of Adam Smith, who made this claim in An Inquiry into the Nature and Causes of the Wealth of Nations, and it still applies today. For example, the European Commission announced on October 1, 2008, that it would fine wax producers 676 million euros for maintaining a price-fixing and market-sharing cartel between 1992 and 2005. Similarly, on November 9, 2010, the European Commission fined eleven airlines a total of 799 million euros for forming a cargo cartel by coordinating surcharges for fuel and security. It is widely accepted that cartels inflict substantial harm on consumers worldwide, amounting to billions of dollars annually (OECD 2002). As a result, collusion continues to be an important topic, and there is a pressing need for additional research into the circumstances that facilitate collusion.

In addition to collusion, firms have other legal and illegal means at their disposal in their quest to increase profits. For many national governments, tax evasion is a matter of growing concern. While the groundbreaking analyses on the subject of tax evasion have focused on the individual's compliance decision (e.g., Allingham and Sandmo 1972; Yitzhaki 1974), tax evasion by firms is also an important consideration. Slemrod (2007, 31), for example, reports for the United States that “the IRS estimates noncompliance with the corporation income tax in 2001 to be $30 billion, which corresponds to a noncompliance rate of 17%.”

The present article analyzes how a firm’s decision to evade taxes interacts with its decision to collude. We establish that tax evasion may either promote or hinder cartelization of the industry, that is the fact that firms in the industry evade taxes may make it either more difficult or easier to form a stable cartel. When firms decide whether or not to deviate from a cartel agreement, they compare the profits they would obtain from continued loyalty to the cartel to the total profits they would earn in deviation and punishment phases, should they deviate from the cartel. The cartel is deemed to be stable when the expected present value of profits resulting from loyalty to the cartel surpasses the expected present total value of the higher profits during deviation and the subsequent lower profits in the punishment phase. In most cases, tax evasion affects respective profit levels disproportionately, thereby influencing the condition for stable collusion. The direction of the effect of tax evasion on collusion is established to ultimately depend on the shape of concealment costs, that is, the costs associated with the concealment of tax evasion. Having established that incentives for tax evasion and cartelization interact, we then observe that enforcement directed at one transgression will also influence the level of the other transgression. In this regard, we highlight the possibility that stricter tax enforcement may make collusion more tempting for firms and thereby may result in a higher level of tax evasion. However, stricter antitrust enforcement does not provoke similarly counterintuitive effects. These findings may be taken to imply that stricter antitrust enforcement is a safer method of addressing both kinds of illegal behavior, as stricter tax enforcement may backfire.

Our contribution to the literature is threefold. First, we establish that tax evasion has important repercussions for firms’ incentives to collude. Second, the present article establishes that changes in antitrust enforcement imply changes in the level of taxes evaded and that tax enforcement policy can influence the likelihood that a cartel will be formed (which in turn can result in unintended consequences for the rate of tax evasion). Third, our analysis contributes to the literature delimiting the circumstances under which the decision to evade taxes has no impact on the firm’s activity choice (e.g., Yaniv 1995). In the article at hand, the firm's activity choice is unaffected at the margin but could be influenced by variations in the likelihood of stable collusion.

sec.title: Relation to the Literature
sec.p: The effect of tax evasion on the likelihood of collusion has—to the best of our knowledge—not yet been examined, despite the fact that the determinants of stable collusion have long been the subject of study (see, e.g., chapter 4 in Motta 2004). These determinants include multimarket contacts and firm cost asymmetries. Symeonidis (2002) studies the consequence of multiproduct firms on the incentives to collude, while Symeonidis (2003) establishes the influences of capital and advertising intensity. Further factors that may make collusion easier or more difficult to sustain are discussed in the comprehensive surveys by, for example, Feuerstein (2005) and Kaplow and Shapiro (2007). More directly related to the present study, both Haufler and Schjelderup (2004) and Schindler and Schjelderup (2009) analyze the nexus of taxation and tacit collusion but with a focus on the relationship between international taxation and cartel stability. Our article adds a further important dimension to the discussion of factors influencing cartel stability—namely, the finding that the possibility for firms to evade taxes may strengthen cartelization incentives under certain circumstances.

Tax evasion by individuals has attracted a great deal of scholarly attention (see, e.g., the survey by Slemrod and Yitzhaki 2000). Tax evasion by competitive firms has been analyzed by, among others, Virmani (1989) and Cremer and Gahvari (1993), while tax evasion by firms with market power has been addressed by Marelli (1984) and Marelli and Martina (1988). In fact, Marelli and Martina (1988) study the possible interaction between privately optimal output levels for duopolistic firms and their tax evasion decisions by undertaking a comparative statics analysis in which the conjectural variation (i.e., the way in which firms respond to changes in the output level of the other firm) is exogenously varied. Since tax evasion depends on equilibrium output levels, changes in the conjectural variation influence tax evasion by firms. The present article differs in focus and analytical structure from Marelli and Martina (1988). First, we are interested in studying whether the endogenous decision to form a cartel is affected by the decision regarding tax evasion. Second, we make use of a repeated-game setting in order to determine whether compliance with cartel behavior is incentive compatible for the individual firm, whereas the study by Marelli and Martina focuses on a one-period setting. Goerke and Runkel (2011) revisit the interaction of competition and tax evasion in a homogeneous good setting with an endogenous number of firms, focusing exclusively on the issue of sales tax. They establish that an increase in the number of firms induced by lower market-entry costs aggravates tax evasion incentives because firms substitute tax evasion for the loss in market power as they seek to maximize profits. The present article analyzes the interaction between tax evasion and incentives for collusion for a given number of firms. Bayer and Cowell (2009) similarly consider firms that compete in quantity and may evade taxes, investigating the effect of different audit rules: a fixed audit rule under which the audit probability is not dependent on the vector of firms’ tax-base declarations, and a relative rule that includes this dependency. While they also consider the possibility of collusion, Bayer and Cowell (2009) are not interested in the likelihood of collusion. The present article focuses on this latter aspect.

In addition, our study revisits the previous finding that tax evasion does not affect firms’ activity choice (for early contributions, see Kreutzer and Lee 1986; Wang and Conant 1988; and Wang 1990). Yaniv (1995) establishes a generic model in which firm activity is generally separable from the decision to evade taxes; this is an important component of our model as well. Three other recent contributions that establish the limits of the separability result are provided by Panteghini (2000), Goerke and Runkel (2006), and Baumann and Friehe (2010). 1 In the present article, the output decision of the firm may depend on tax evasion, since the latter can affect the formation of a cartel.

The article is structured as follows: the second section presents a description of the model. The third section analyzes how tax evasion may influence the incentives to form a cartel followed by the discussion on the interdependence of tax enforcement and antitrust enforcement. In the fifth section, we provide a numerical example in order to ease the understanding of the theoretical model and to illustrate the interdependence of enforcement mechanisms. The last section offers concluding remarks.

sec.title: The Model
sec.p: The model describes the calculus of n symmetric and risk-neutral firms that play a two-stage subgame an infinite number of times. 2 During the first stage of the subgame, firms decide whether to form a cartel; this influences the choice of activity in the second stage of the subgame. The firm decides on its activity level and the amount of taxes to evade during the second stage. Firms can evade taxes either by misreporting sales or profits or by making false declarations regarding input use. The modeling in the first stage focuses on the stability condition for cartel formation (i.e., the corresponding critical discount factor). The arguments related to the second stage closely follow the model established by Yaniv (1995), which is specific neither to a certain tax base nor to the structure of the market in which the firm is active. There are three different modes of operation that must be distinguished: cartel (K), in which a cartel is formed and firms comply with cartel requirements in terms of activity level; deviation (D), in which firms agree to form a cartel but one firm deviates from the activity level recommendation; and competition (C), in which firms maximize profits noncooperatively, for example, after the breakdown of a cartel. The extent of tax evasion at stage 2 will depend on the modus operandi in effect. In turn, how tax evasion alters profits at stage 2 will co-determine the decision regarding whether to form a cartel in the first stage. The model is solved by backward induction.

sec.title: Stage 1
sec.p:
Collusive agreements are inherently unstable in a static setting, since deviation is always profitable in the short run. However, stability may be obtained in a multiperiod setting, since punishment for deviant behavior may allow collusion in equilibrium. The size of the discount factor δ with which future payments are discounted is of critical importance in this regard, as it will determine whether the ensuing lower profits in the punishment phase after deviation will outweigh the onetime increase in profits in the deviation period. We consider the following standard trigger strategy: firms (1) start cooperatively, (2) maintain cooperative behavior if no firm has deviated in the past, and (3) revert to the competitive outcome forever, should any firm deviate from the collusive agreement. 5 Consequently, we assume for simplicity that past behavior is perfectly observable. As an additional impediment to collusion, we consider that collusive behavior may be sanctionable. Indeed, many countries outlaw collusion. However, in some countries, competition law exists primarily on the books and is not enforced (Gal 2009). In principle, competition authorities have control over the detection probability q ≥ 0 and the fine imposed F > 0 in the event of detected collusion. In the following analysis, we distinguish between effective (q > 0) and ineffective (q = 0) antitrust enforcement. In line with the majority of the literature, we assume that the fine is independent of the number of periods in which collusion has occurred (see, e.g., Motta and Polo 2003). In reality, sanctions levied on transgressors by antitrust authorities are often dependent on the profit gain resulting from membership in a cartel. 6 Therefore, we can represent the level of the fine as fixed at

In other words, the firm’s decision regarding whether to collude depends on the difference between profits from deviation and collusion on one hand, and the difference between profits from deviation and competition on the other. Consequently, the impact of the possibility to evade taxes on the likelihood of collusion (i.e., the level of the critical discount factor) hinges on the relative influence of these differences. In the presence of effective cartel enforcement, the ranking of the respective critical discount factors is somewhat complicated, as the expected fine for collusion must be incorporated. However, the central question in this regard is always whether the transformation of legal after-tax profits implies that firms are more tempted to deviate from any given cartel agreement. For the case in which
q = 0
(i.e., no effective cartel law enforcement), firms are clearly more (less) tempted by the opportunity to deviate when the total expected profits are strictly convex (concave), because this implies that deviation profits are—with regard to the absolute impact—affected most (least) by the transformation. When the deviation option is relatively more attractive, this is reflected in a higher level of the critical discount factor, because successful cartel formation would require greater weight on the loss in a firm’s profits during the punishment phase.

sec.title: Enforcement Policies
sec.p: The analysis considers two different offenses: firms may break antitrust and/or tax laws. To enforce its laws, the state maintains a detection probability and sanctions for both transgressions. This article focuses on the interaction between firms' decisions on tax evasion and on collusion. As we have established the interdependence between these respective decisions, it follows that the impact of the enforcement of the two laws will have more far-reaching effects than is generally assumed. Consequently, it is of interest to observe how a change in enforcement directed at one offense could impact the prevalence of the other.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This article analyzes the interaction between tax evasion and collusion. Tax evasion in most circumstances affects the payoffs from loyalty to a cartel agreement, deviation from such an agreement, and competitive conditions to different degrees. Tax evasion thus impacts the range of discount factors compatible with stable collusion. Consequently, we contribute to the literature by highlighting a hitherto neglected factor that affects the likelihood of collusion in a given industry.

Moreover, the finding on the interdependence of decisions on tax evasion and collusion proves that the activity choice of firms may no longer be independent from tax evasion if the possibility to form a cartel is taken into account. Changes in the critical discount factor imply that for some discount factors, collusion may occur under one of the two settings, but not in the other. Firm and industry activity levels are dependent on whether collusion occurs. We establish a link between tax evasion and firm activity levels and thereby contribute to the literature that identifies circumstances in which the separability result does not apply.

Finally, we stress that isolated enforcement may have unintended consequences. While stricter cartel law enforcement is likely to help reduce tax evasion, an increase in the audit probability may make it easier to stabilize collusion and thus ultimately result in more tax evasion, if firms evade more in the collusive state. Our article therefore points to possible detrimental effects of decentralized decision making in the realm of law enforcement that could affect the optimal policy mix.

The question of whether tax evasion promotes or hinders cartelization has been shown to depend to a large extent on the concealment costs that firms incur when evading taxes. From a purely theoretical standpoint, it is difficult to judge which specification is most likely to represent concealment costs incurred by real-world firms. However, given this factor’s importance in our analysis, attempts at empirical assessment would be highly desirable.
